body:
I'm using this pattern in about 4 places in my company's app personally and I found another 6 places where another developer used it.

Here's the most basic example I can think of:

```ruby
profile = @user.profile || @user.profile.build
profile.update_attributes(...)

# or
@user.profile.update_or_create(attributes)
```

Other real world examples include setting up a row in a payment processing information table, looping through financial transactions to create or update approved amounts, syncing up a cached feed item with the parent content item, updating membership log entries, etc.

The proposed version also supports blocks for protected attributes. I think it does deserve some more discussion on how it operates a `has_many` vs `has_one` -- but `#update_attributes` only works on a single record so I designed the API for the method with that in mind [1].

I do understand your concern about method bloat (and I *hate* bloat), but I did see this as a common pattern in our application.

So given we have the following in the API:

- first_or_create[!]
- first_or_initialize
- update_or_create

Can we think of any other similar methods that would want to be added that could cause bloat? I think these cover all common patterns.

Thanks for taking the time to look at this pull.

[1] Off topic, but would you consider accepting a pull for `#update_attributes` allowing a block for protected attributes? via `record.tap(&block)`?
